Description: Shield made of hippopotamus hide with a boss in the centre of silver, as are the plates in the rim; at the base of the boss are attached eight leather pockets containing charms.
Curator's comments: Register records: "From the desert eastwards of the Nile between Secattim [Suakin] and the frontiers of Egypt. They may be consiidered the ancient armour of the Bisharies, for most of this tribe are now probably armed with guns."
Acquisition notes: Af1853,0422.1 to 11 were collected and given by Colonel William Martin Leake. They must come from the years 1801-2 when after the capitulation of the French Army in August 1801, he "was employed until March 1802 in making a general survey of Egypt in conjunction with Lord Elgin's secretary, William Richard Hamilton. He went as far south as the cataracts of the Nile" (see his biography in the DNB). The notes that he supplied with some of the objects suggest that he had reached as far as the 5th cataract in modern Sudan, and made excursions into the Nubian desert. Some of the objects might have come from the modern Eritrea/Ethiopia.
